How about our feature distributions? ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_long = df.melt(id_vars='Class label') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} import seaborn as sns sns.violinplot(data = df_long, x = 'variable', y = 'value') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=48} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-7-output-2.png){width=645 height=429} ::: ::: Makes sense to normalise our data. ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler # create a scaler object scaler = MinMaxScaler() # fit and transform the data df_norm = pd.DataFrame(scaler.fit_transform(df), columns=df.columns) df_long = df_norm.melt(id_vars='Class label') df_long ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=49} ```{=html}

How about a pairplot? ::: {.cell .column-page execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.pairplot(data = df_norm.iloc[:,1:]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-10-output-1.png){width=3062 height=3061} ::: ::: Hmm, a few interesting correlations. Some of our variables are skewed. We could apply some PCA here to look at fewer dimension or even log transform some of the skewed variables. For now we will just run a kmeans cluster and then check our results against the ground truth. Lets decide how many clusters we need. ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.cluster import KMeans ks = range(1, 10) inertias = [] for k in ks: # Create a KMeans instance with k clusters: model model = KMeans(n_clusters=k, n_init = 10) # Fit model to samples model.fit(df.iloc[:,1:]) # Append the inertia to the list of inertias inertias.append(model.inertia_) import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot(ks, inertias, '-o', color='black') plt.xlabel('number of clusters, k') plt.ylabel('inertia') plt.xticks(ks) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-11-output-1.png){width=597 height=443} ::: ::: What happens if we use the normalised data instead? ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.cluster import KMeans ks = range(1, 10) inertias = [] for k in ks: # Create a KMeans instance with k clusters: model model = KMeans(n_clusters=k, n_init = 10) # Fit model to samples model.fit(df_norm.iloc[:,1:]) # Append the inertia to the list of inertias inertias.append(model.inertia_) import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot(ks, inertias, '-o', color='black') plt.xlabel('number of clusters, k') plt.ylabel('inertia') plt.xticks(ks) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-1.png){width=585 height=429} ::: ::: Both of the graphs are the same. Is that what you would expect? Three clusters seems about right (and matches our number of origonal labels). ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['Class label'].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=54} ``` Class label 2 71 1 59 3 48 Name: count, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Create a KMeans instance with k clusters: model k_means = KMeans(n_clusters=3) # Fit model to samples df_k_means = k_means.fit(df.iloc[:,1:]) df['Three clusters'] = pd.Series(df_k_means.predict(df.iloc[:,1:].values), index = df.index) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=55} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: It might be easier to see as a stacked plot (see [this post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43544694/using-pandas-crosstab-with-seaborn-stacked-barplots)). ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np ct.plot.bar(stacked=True) plt.legend(title='Class label') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=57} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-16-output-2.png){width=566 height=425} ::: ::: How has the kmeans model done compared to our ground truth? We need to be really careful here. We notice that it is not easily possible to compare the known class labels to clustering labels. The reason is that the clustering algorithm labels are just arbitrary and not assigned to any deterministic criteria. Each time you run the algorithm, you might get a different id for the labels. The reason is that the label itself doesn't actually mean anything, what is important is the list of items that are in the same cluster and their relations. A way to come over this ambiguity and evaluate the results is to look at a visualisations of the results and compare. But this brings in the question of what type of visualisation to use for looking at the clusters. An immediate alternative is to use scatterplots. However, it is not clear which axis to use for clustering. A common method to apply at this stage is to make use of PCA to get a 2D plane where we can project the data points and visualise them over this projection. ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[:,1:14] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=58} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.decomposition import PCA n_components = 2 pca = PCA(n_components=n_components) df_pca = pca.fit(df.iloc[:,1:14]) df_pca_vals = df_pca.transform(df.iloc[:,1:14]) ``` ::: Grab our projections and plot along with our cluster names. ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['c1'] = [item[0] for item in df_pca_vals] df['c2'] = [item[1] for item in df_pca_vals] ax = sns.scatterplot(data = df, x = 'c1', y = 'c2', hue = 'Class label') ax.set_title('Known labels visualised over PCs') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=60} ``` Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Known labels visualised over PCs') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-19-output-2.png){width=612 height=449} ::: ::: In the figure above, we colored the points based on the actual labels, we observe that there has been several misclassifications in the figure above (i.e., in the algorithm's results). So one may choose to use an alternative algorithm or devise a better distance metric. ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} ax = sns.scatterplot(data = df, x = 'c1', y = 'c2', hue = 'Three clusters') ax.set_title('Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=61} ``` Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-20-output-2.png){width=612 height=449} ::: ::: This shows the parallelism between the clustering algorithm and PCA. By looking at the PCA loadings, we can find out what the x-axis mean and try to interpret the clusters (We leave this as an additional exercise for those interested). How might your interpret the above plots? Did the kmeans model identify the ground truth? How robust is our clustering? It may be that the kmeans algorithm becamse stuck or that a few outliers have biased the clustering. Two ways to check are: * Running the model multiple times with different initial values. * Removing some data and running the modelling multiple times. Run the below cell a few times. What do you see? ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Create a KMeans instance with k clusters: model k_means = KMeans(n_clusters=3, init='random', n_init = 10) # Fit model to samples df_k_means = k_means.fit(df.iloc[:,1:14]) df['Three clusters'] = pd.Series(df_k_means.predict(df.iloc[:,1:14].values), index = df.index) ax = sns.scatterplot(data = df, x = 'c1', y = 'c2', hue = 'Three clusters') ax.set_title('Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=62} ``` Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-21-output-2.png){width=612 height=449} ::: ::: How about with only 80% of the data? ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_sample = df.sample(frac=0.8, replace=False) # Create a KMeans instance with k clusters: model k_means = KMeans(n_clusters=3, init='random', n_init = 10) # Fit model to samples df_k_means = k_means.fit(df_sample.iloc[:,1:14]) df_sample['Three clusters'] = pd.Series(df_k_means.predict(df_sample.iloc[:,1:14].values), index = df_sample.index) ax = sns.scatterplot(data = df_sample, x = 'c1', y = 'c2', hue = 'Three clusters') ax.set_title('Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=63} ``` Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Results of the algorithm visualised over PCs') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_5_1_files/figure-html/cell-22-output-2.png){width=612 height=449} ::: ::: We may want to automate the process of resampling the data or rerunning the model then perhaps plotting the different inertia values or creating different plots. Do you think our clustering algorithm is stable and provide similiar results even when some data is removed or the initial values are random? If so, then is our algorithm capturing the ground truth?
